ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I appreciated the way this course was set up in that certain weeks were dedicated to certain Central American countries. This allowed for an in-depth focus on each major country. I appreciated how the course material focused on Indigenous and Afro-Central American communities and voices of resistance against colonial violence.
Background and themes on central american history and frameworks to understand race, nationality and diaspora relating to its populations.
I learned about basic sociological methods and I learned about the histories of every Central American country. I received a lot of help with the final paper.

In this class, I was able to learn about the wars in Central America, specifically in El Salvador. The course covered topics such as immigration, fear, activism, and the ways in which Central Americans have established themselves in the country. This class emphasizes Central American studies as an important field of study. Through readings of works by scholars like Zamora and Tenorio, among others, we delved deeper into the understanding of what it means to be Central American in the U.S. By the end of this course, I felt that I was contributing to a community, as the final project was designed for us to contribute to the community within the field of study.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: readings were very interesting, professor facilitated class discussion in an engaging way by giving us guiding questions for discussion and different activities; clear feedback received on final project proposal
Weaknesses: high amount of readings sometimes
I really liked the intimate setting of our class that made every meeting feel very welcoming and engaging. No class was ever the same.
Strengths are the readings the professor and the discussions that helped us produce the final paper. I wish the readings were shorter and that we discussed them more in class.

I fell in love with the content discussed in this course. I believe it is crucial as it provides a profound insight into the Central American experience. The professor's relaxed teaching style creates a comfortable environment, especially when addressing sensitive topics. However, I wish the class could be spread across two days each week to alleviate the stress associated with extensive reading and the draining nature of back-to-back classes. Adjusting the schedule could potentially allow for a more relaxed atmosphere, enabling students to analyze and contemplate the content more effectively.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if you are interested in learning more about Central American communities. The course content is very engaging and class was always so interesting and fun because of the way that Dr. Hidalgo facilitated class.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This is a population that even within the understudied field of latinx studies goes unrecognized and generalized within academia, and as someone living in the US it is your responsibility to learn more about Central American Studies.
Absolutely! Take the course regardless of what your major is. The topics are relevant and interesting.

I wholeheartedly recommend this course to anyone interested in Central American studies. It emphasizes the significance of understanding the unique identities within each country. If you're someone who enjoys exploring topics such as war, immigration, identity politics, and power dynamics, this class is tailored for you. It prompted me to consider the importance of other courses that delve into Central American studies as well.

I would highly recommend this course to students interested in Central American studies and/or the topic of immigration. Professor Hidalgo does a wonderful job of organizing the class and is incredibly receptive to student feedback regarding its structure. I found the readings and the activities we engaged in within class to be extremely engaging as well.

extras.title: ER&M 383 01/SOCY 383 01 - Central Americans in the U.S.
